newsitem.title: USA: U.S. refiners reluctant to take North Sea crudes.
newsitem.headline: U.S. refiners reluctant to take North Sea crudes.

text.p: U.S. refiners seemed reluctant to take North Sea crude cargoes on offer Friday amid slim downstream margins, traders said.

The spread between February West Texas Intermediate and North Sea Brent was around $1.50-55 a barrel late Friday, up around five cents from late Thursday, maintaining the open trans-Atlantic arbitrage.
Several Wall Street players are offering Brent cargoes for early February arrival to the Gulf Coast at February West Texas Intermediate minus 25 cents, trade sources said.
"It's got to be at least 40 cents (under WTI) to get our attention," one refiner said.
The open arbitrage and slim margins, meanwhile, have taken a toll on other regional crudes, such as Colombia's Cusiana.
British Petroleum sold a 550,000 barrel cargo of Cusiana to a Gulf Coast refiner for delivery January 23-24 at a premium of 10 cents to March WTI, traders said.
Before Christmas, Cusiana was fetching a premium of around 40 cents, traders said.
BP has a second cargo on offer for January 31 to February 1 at around the same price, trade sources said.
In other Latin American activity, Uruguay's state-owned oil company ANCAP bought asphaltic crude for delivery February 12-14 in a private spot transaction with Venezuela, trade sources said.
ANCAP bought BCF-24 crude from Lagoven, a unit of state-owned Petroleos de Venezuela, they said.
The cargo of around 500,000 barrels will load between January 30 and February 2, they said.
Traders speculated that ANCAP paid around $5.00 a barrel under benchmark West Texas Intermediate for the cargo.
Uruguay normally buys around one million barrels a year of such crude for asphalt, and has previously bought heavy Saudi and Iranian crudes, traders said.
In the U.S. aftermarket, a series of partial February Brent cargoes changed hands at $24.18 and 24.20 a barrel, up nine to 11 cents from the IPE settlement.
Intermonth spreads were also stronger. Feb/Mar Brent traded at 52/53 cents, up four to five cents from the London close.
